talk.start.para: asked the Minister for

quote.para: What progress has been made, since his answer to me on 11th October 1966 (Hansard, page 1594), in applying:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1960

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Convention relating to the Limitation of the Liability of the Owners of Sea-going Ships, 1957

item.label: (c)
item.para: The Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1960

item.label: (d)
item.para: The Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules Relating to the Carriage of Passengers by Sea, 1961, and

item.label: (e)
item.para: The Amendments to the International Convention for the Prevention of the Pollution of the Sea by Oil, 1962 to:

item.label: (i)
item.para: Overseas

item.label: (ii)
item.para: Interstate

item.label: (iii)
item.para: Territorial and

item.label: (iv)
item.para: Intrastate Shipping.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1960 are now fully applied by legislation both by the Commonwealth and by each of the States.

item.label: (b)
item.para: No further progress has been made in the drafting of a model bill to be considered by the Commonwealth and State governments since my last answer, but the complex legal issues involved are still receiving consideration.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The Bill to amend the Navigation Act to permit acceptance of the Safety of Life at Sea Convention 1960 has, of course, just been passed by Parliament and drafting of the complex and voluminous amendments to Regulations is well advanced. State governments are considering whether their legislation requires any amendment, and discussions have been held with the Department of Territories concerning the extension of the Convention to Australian Territories, but these factors will not delay Australia's acceptance of the Convention which is expected to be deposited in the near future.

item.label: (d)
item.para: As mentioned in my previous answer, little international interest has been shown in respect of this Convention, and it appears likely that it will eventually be amended.

item.label: (e)
item.para: The 1962 Amendments to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil, 1954, came fully into force internationally on 28th June 1967; the Commonwealth's Pollution of the Sea by Oil Act 1965 was proclaimed to come into force on that date and the necessary amendments of the Commonwealth's Pollution of the Sea by Oil Regulations also became operative from that date. In the State sphere a draft model bill has been approved by the Australian Port Authorities Association. It is expected that appropriate bills will now be introduced into State parliaments and that the necessary State regulations will be drafted. The model bill is also serving as a basis for amendment of Territorial legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice:

item.para: When was the text of the Internation il Convention on Load Lines, 1966, and five related

answer.para: Recommendations sent to the State governments and Department of Territories, and what were the dates and nature of their replies?

item.para: Can he yet say what (a) administrative and (b) legislative action will be taken by (i) the Commonwealth, (ii) the States and (iii) the Territories in respect of the Convention and Recommendations and when it will be taken (Hansard, 13th September 1966, pages 824 and 827)?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: It is not usual for information of the type requested by the honourable member to be made public, unless it is mutually agreed between the Commonwealth and the State Government concerned to do so. No such agreement has been made in this case and the information therefore cannot be made available. 2. (i) In the Commonwealth's sphere the Government has approved the acceptance by Australia of the Convention. The necessary amendments of the Navigation Act and the Navigation (Load Lines) Regulations are being prepared in order to apply the new provisions to ships on international and interstate voyages. It is hoped to have this legislation ready in time for the provisions of the new Convention to be applied in Australia when they come into force internationally on 21st July 1968.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The State Premiers have been informed that the Commonwealth Government has approved acceptance by Australia and that the necessary legislation is being prepared to apply the new provisions to ships engaged on interstate as well as international voyages.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: The Department of Territories advises that no action is required in respect of the Northern Territory but amendment of the Papua and New Guinea legislation will be necessary.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration, upon notice:

item.para: ls it a fact that in Western Australia migrants arc allowed to stay in hostels for 2 years and in the proposed new flats will be permitted to stay for 6 months?
Was there an increase of 3,400 migrants in the State for the 12 months ending 30th June 1967, making the total intake 14,000?

What is being done to increase the number of houses to provide for the increased number of migrants to Western Australia and at the same time provide housing for people on the already overloaded waiting list?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: Accommodation in hostels is provided for migrants sponsored by the Commonwealth itself.

answer.para: Such accommodation is essentially transitory and bridges the gap between arrival and the acquisition of permanent accommodation.
There is one Commonwealth Migrant Hostel in Western Australia, situated at Graylands. Tha maximum period of residence permitted at this and all other Commonwealth hostels is 2 years.

The State Government of Western Australia also operates a migrant reception centre at Point Waller and is building a new one at Bull Creek. The Commonwealth contributes half the capital cost of State reception centres. The conditions of residence are determined by the State Government.
Migrants in Commonwealth hostels are encouraged to move to private accommodation as soon as possible and the average stay in hostels is now 29 weeks.

An Accommodation Advisory Service has been established to assist residents in hostels to obtain suitable private accommodation. Since August 1966, this Service has helped 2,333 families involving 10,742 persons to find accommodation outside hostels.

Self-contained flats as initial transitory accommodation for migrants are to be introduced experimentally in Western Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales. Occupancy is to bo limited to 6 months. - 2. Final figures are not yet available for tha year ended 30th June 1967.
During the financial year 1965-66, 14,020 persons named Western Australia as their State of intended residence.
Arrivals in Western Australia during the period July 1966-March 1967 numbered 13,485. In the same period in 1965-66 the figure was 10,244.

item.para: I am informed by my colleague, the Minister for Housing, that in Western Australia the combined housing production of Government (about 15% of the total output) and private enterprise, has been running at very high levels and in the current quarter conditions are favourable for at least a continuation of this trend.

answer.para: This year, through the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement, Western Australia's allocation will reach $1Om which is $830,000 more than last year.

In conditions where immigration has shown such a satisfying upward trend some degree of pressure on resources cannot be avoided. It is, therefore, gratifying to see that the number of houses and flats approved in Western Australia in the June quarter was 3,388 which was some 650 more than the previous quarter, and nearly one-third more than the June quarter of last year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social

item.para: Can he advise the amount of assistance each State provides for (a) deserted wives during the first six months of desertion and (b) wives of husband prisoners during a period of imprisonment of up to 6 months?
Does any State require the repayment of any of this assistance?
What assistance is provided for dependent children in each case?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: As this question relates to assistance given by the States it would be more appropriate for the honourable member to seek the information directly from the States.
The honourable member will recall that the right honourable the Treasurer stated in the Budget Speech:

We intend to open discussions with the States with the object of working out mutually acceptable arrangements for the assistance of deserted wives and wives of prisoners. At present these women are, subject to a means test and other conditions, eligible for a widow's pension if they have been deserted, or if the husband has been in prison, for not less than 6 months. Meanwhile, they can approach the State authorities in most States for assistance, with assistance varying considerably from State to State. The right honourable the Prime Minister in currently in correspondence with the State Premiere in order to make arrangements for the proposed discussions.
